page.title: 01The Landscape
page.content: The area stretches from Seisdon in the west to the Staffordshire County Boundary at Wolverhampton in the east and from a line running through the hamlet of Trescott to Merryhill in the north to Trysull and Wombourne in the south. It includes part of the village of Seisdon ,which gave its name to the old County Hundred in Saxon times; Trysull, Orton, and Lower Penn villages; and a small part of Wombourne village: Mixed farming is the chief occupation with some quarrying of sand and gravel in the south-west. The area is very open with little woodland and having had many hedgerows taken out to create larger,more economic fields. Several roads run between high banks. Overhead electric power lines,radiating from Ebstree,dominate the scenery.
